title: Liverpool news: 'Highly offensive' Divock Origi banner unveiled at Genk
text:
The ‘highly offensive’ banner was unveiled in the away end at Genk (Picture: Rex Features)

Liverpool have slammed their own supporters for unveiling a racist banner ahead of their Champions League clash with Genk, mocking Divock Origi.

The large banner, unfurled in the away end, showed Origi’s face superimposed onto a picture of a black man holding an extremely large penis, from a widely distributed meme known as ‘WhasApp Guy.’

Also depicted on the banner is the Liverpool club logo and the Champions League trophy.

Liverpool officials called for the banner to be taken down, which duly happened, and the club were swift to issue a statement making it clear that the image is completely unacceptable.

(Picture: Rex Features)

A statement read: ‘Liverpool Football Club condemns the offensive banner displayed in our section of the ground, prior to kick off.

‘To be clear, the image used perpetuated a racist stereotype.

‘This is completely unacceptable. We have acted swiftly to have the banner removed and we are now working with the local authorities and stadium team in Genk to identify those responsible.

‘Any subsequent action will be taken in keeping with our sanctions process.’

It is yet to be confirmed whether those responsible have been identified and what punishment they will face.

On the pitch it was much better news for the Reds as they took the lead through an Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain strike in just the second minute.
